ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Expanded math skills.
Learned a lot about integrals, FTC, convergence/divergence, rotation, polar
I've learned the fundamentals and applications of integral calculus.
Basic overview of Calculus concepts including integration, series, parametric, and polar systems.
I learned calculus. The pacing of this class was way too fast and not enough emphasis was placed on practicing new skills.
I learned calculus
Calculus BC
I expanded my knowledge on the fundamentals of calculus.
We learned the skills necessary to complete MATH 115

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
S: my teacher Rachel

W: so much pressure on the tests
The grades are too heavily dependent on 3 tests, which should not determine your entire grade.

This course could benefit from optional review sessions that aren't as personal as office hours, but rather recaps of weekly information. The content was not too difficult but could sometimes require more outside learning other than PSETs.
Lots of opportunities to practice and learn through our exploration quizzes, class was very informative and gave us time to work on problems in small groups

This course does not place enough emphasis on practice. The course material is taught way to quickly to be fully absorbed. The change between sequences and series is too abrupt to fully learn the difference between the two. I especially found it detrimental to be introduced to new material during the week of the midterm or final. I would not say that students are focused on learning new topics when they are struggling to grasp old ones. Having a PSet due the day before a midterm is also pretty cruel. Students are trying to focus on studying and the added pressure of another grade does not help. I liked how for the final the Pset was not submitted. This allowed for me to practice for my understanding instead of worrying about a grade. Overall, I struggled keeping up with this class, even as a frequent attendee of my professor's office hours and peer tutor hours.
It would be nice if they lectures were recorded
I think that there shouldve been more recordings plus the other professors teaching it definitely need improvement.

It was too fast and I found it very bad. The speed was quick and on top of that there was little engagement. I also hatted that everyone else did 24 hour midterm/finals so I was accustomed to that, not these very limited 1.5 hour tests. I dont want to sound so harsh but there was really nothing I thought was good about the course except the concept checks.

It was well paced, and fairly easy to keep up with the work and understand the material. I don't really have any complaints besides that I felt the explorations that we had to do before the lectures weren't particularly helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Math is hard to learn online.
More chapter tests/quizzes to help ensure we will learn the concepts as soon as they are taught rather than letting it sit until the midtermd
The class felt personally disconnected from the professor and the fellow students. Sitting with all of our cameras off seems bleak with little interaction with each other or the content.

This class did its best, but learning math over Zoom is hard. It was a challenge to show my teacher my work. I had to hold it up to my camera and the teacher had to try to find what I did wrong. This was not always helpful.
The prefecture work
I think given the time of the class and Covid, it was as engaging as it could be.
Being able to enter class in seconds was a success. Everything else was bad.

The explorations we were required to do before the lectures, didn't really help me with the material at all, and felt like busy work. Besides that, I thought this course did a good job of being engaging and easy to understand in an online format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, need to take it for a lot of majors.
I would recommend this course for anyone trying to fill requirements for their major. Otherwise, I feel like the amount of time dedication for this class would not be enjoyable.
Yes but only if you need it for a prerequisite of major requirement.
I would not recommend this class to anyone who does not need to take it. It is very fast-paced and assumes that you will pick concepts up quickly.
Yes
I would recommend it in person with Rachel.
In the same setting I took it, with COVID restrictions at least, absolutely not.
Yes, specifically with Professor Diethorn.
For sure. It is an excellent math course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Asynchronous skills quizzes and videos to get introduced to concepts before class
This class was a lecture but we also participated vocally in class.
None
None
